facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 109 of 1954 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 21, 1950, of the former Nagpur High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 135 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 109 of 1954. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 21, 1950, of the former Nagpur High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 135 of 1949.

facts.text: A sum of Rs. 2,50,000 was received by the respondent on August 2, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: the point that is raised for our determination is whether a sum of Rs. 2,50,000 received by the respondent on August 2, 1941, is chargeable to income- tax.

facts.text: The Department considers the amount of Rs. 2,50,000 as a revenue receipt liable to be included in the chargeable income.

anchor.surface_text: the point that is raised for our determination is whether a sum of Rs. 2,50,000 received by the respondent on August 2, 1941, is chargeable to income- tax. While, according to the Department, the amount in question is a revenue receipt liable to be included in the chargeable income,

facts.text: The respondent considers the amount of Rs. 2,50,000 as a capital receipt not liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: according to the respondent it is capital receipt number liable to tax.

facts.text: The Appellate Tribunal held that the amount was a trading receipt and income liable to be assessed, affirming ITO and AAC.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal held, affirming the decisions of the Income-tax Officer and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, that the amount in question was a trading receipt, and was income liable to be assessed.

facts.text: High Court (Sen and Deo JJ) held the sum of Rs. 2,50,000 was a capital receipt not liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: The reference was heard by Sen and Deo, JJ., who held, disagreeing with the Tribunal, that the sum of Rs. 2,50,000 was a capital receipt in the hands of the respondent, and that it, was number liable to be taxed.

facts.text: Appellant applied for certificate under s.66A to appeal to Supreme Court, but dismissed by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then filed an application under s. 66 A  2  of the Act for a certificate to appeal to this Court, but that was dismissed,

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave under Art. 136.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter applied to this Court for special leave under Art. 136, and the same was granted, and hence this appeal.

facts.text: Respondent is a businessman whose trading activities include being a railway contractor, running a rice mill and sugar factory, supplier of limestone and dolomite.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is a businessman whose trading activities run in several channels. He is a railway companytractor he runs a rice mill and a sugar factory he is a supplier Of limestone and dolomite.

facts.text: Respondent had acquired a quarry at Paraghat and was working it and selling limestone to Bengal Iron Company Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: It is with the last of these businesses that we are companycerned in these proceedings. The respondent had acquired a quarry at Paraghat and had been himself working it and selling limestone quarried out of it to, among others, a Company called the Bengal Iron Company, Ltd.

facts.text: On January 5, 1935, Bengal Iron Company entered into agreement with respondent for purchase of all its requirements of limestone and dolomite at specified rates.

anchor.surface_text: On January 5, 1935, the said Company entered into an agreement with the respondent for the purchase of all its requirements of limestone and dolomite from  1  1935 A.C. 431.

facts.text: Rates modified by agreement dated December 21, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: and these rates were subsequently modified by another agreement between the parties dated December 21, 1935.

facts.text: In 1936, Bengal Iron Company went into liquidation; assets and liabilities taken over by Indian Iron and Steel Company Ltd. under scheme dated September 8, 1936.

anchor.surface_text: In 1936 the Company went into liquidation, and its assets and liabilities were taken over by another Company called the Indian Iron and Steel Company, Ltd. under a scheme of amalgamation dated September 8, 1936.

facts.text: Indian Iron and Steel Co. informed respondent by notice dated May 29, 1939, that it would purchase from other sources due to uneconomic rates.

anchor.surface_text: but later on, finding that the rates were uneconomic owing to increase in the railway freight, it decided to purchase its requirements from other sources, and by numberice dated May 29, 1939, informed the respondent accordingly.

facts.text: Respondent filed Suit No. 211 of 1940 in Calcutta High Court for specific performance of 1935 contract as modified, and injunction.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the respondent filed Suit No. 211 of 1940 in the High Court of Calcutta for specific performance of the companytract dated January 5, 1935, as modified on December 21, 1935,

facts.text: Injunction issued against Indian Iron and Steel Co. on March 13, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: and on March 13, 1940, an injunction in those terms was actually issued against the Company.

facts.text: Agreement dated May 9, 1940, between Company and respondent settling disputes: respondent to work Gangapur quarry for 25 years, supply limestone.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Company and the respondent entered into an agreement in settlement of all the disputes between them, and the same was embodied in a document dated May 9, 1940.

facts.text: Under May 9, 1940 agreement, respondent to be paid Rs. 4,000 per month for 18 months, then Rs. 2-9-0 per ton.

anchor.surface_text: It was expected that it would take 18 months before the siding companyld be companypleted, and it was agreed that during that period the respondent was to be paid Rs. 4,000 every month. Thereafter, the respondent was to be paid at the rate of Rs. 2-9-0 per ton

facts.text: Railway authorities did not agree to construction of siding at Gangapur.

anchor.surface_text: To companytinue the narration, the railway authorities did number agree to the companystruction at Gangapur of a siding and a loopline to the quarry,

facts.text: New agreement dated August 2, 1941: Company to pay Rs. 2,50,000 as solatium plus unpaid monthly instalments under 1940 contract.

anchor.surface_text: The agreement recites that the Company feeling difficulty in working their mines referred to in the companytract dated May 9, 1940, made a proposal for termination of the said companytract on certain terms, and that was agreed to. The terms of the agreement are  1  that the Company should pay Rs. 2,50,000 to the sellers as solatium

facts.text: Under August 2, 1941 agreement, new contracts: supply limestone for 12 years, loading contractor for iron ore at Monoharpore for 12 years from Jan 1, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: besides the monthly instalments of Rs. 4,000 , remaining unpaid under the companytract dated May 9, 1940  2  that the Company should take all the limestone required for its furnaces at Kulti from the respondent for a period of 12 years

facts.text: Pursuant to August 2, 1941 agreement, respondent was paid Rs. 2,50,000 and balance monthly payments.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this agreement, the respondent was paid a sum of Rs. 2,50,000 and the two agreements relating to the purchase of limestone and the loading of iron ore at Monoharpore were also executed. The balance due on account of monthly payment of Rs. 4,000

facts.text: Respondent claimed before ITO that amount was for termination of 1935 and not 1940 contract.

anchor.surface_text: In his statement before the Income-tax Officer, the respondent merely stated that the amount in question was paid as companysideration for the termination of the companytract of 1935 and number of 1940,

facts.text: Respondent argued capital expenses exceeding Rs. 4 lakhs on 1935 contract works, thrown away, Rs. 2,50,000 reimbursement.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Radha Binode Pal, who appeared for him, argued that for the purpose of carrying out the agreement dated January 5, 1935, the respondent had executed works of a capital nature such as companystruction of quarters, tenements and the like, and had incurred expenses exceeding Rs. 4 lakhs -on that account,

facts.text: Court held no evidence of capital expenses on 1935 contract or connection to Rs. 2,50,000.

anchor.surface_text: There was numberallegation that capital expenses had been incurred in the execution of the companytract of 1935, and that the amount in question was paid as companypensation therefor number is there any evidence on that question.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Rs. 2,50,000 is revenue receipt chargeable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: On a companysideration of all the facts established, we are of opinion that the receipt of Rs. 2,50,000 by the respondent is a revenue receipt. and is chargeable to tax.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, High Court judgment set aside, Tribunal order restored.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, the judgment of the High Court set aside and the order of the Tribunal restored.

facts.text: Respondent supplying limestone and dolomite to Bengal Iron from about 1920.

anchor.surface_text: The record shows that he had been supplying limestone and dolomite to the Bengal Iron Company, Ltd., from about the year 1920

facts.text: Under May 9, 1940 agreement cl.13, respondent not to engage in other contract business within 20 miles except own quarries.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 13 of the agreement enjoined that the respondent was number to engage, during the subsistence of the agreement, in any other companytract business for the working of any quarry within an area of 20 miles from the Companys quarry, but this was subject to the proviso that the respondent was free to work any quarry belonging to and held by him.

anchor.surface_text: for a period of 12 years from January 1, 1942,

anchor.surface_text: The question whether a receipt is capital or income has frequently come up for determination before the courts. Various rules have been enunciated as furnishing a key to the solution of the question, but as often observed by the highest authorities, it is not possible to lay down any single test as infallible or any single criterion as decisive in the determination of the question, which must ultimately depend on the facts of the particular case, and the authorities bearing on the question are valuable only as indicating the matters that have to be taken into account in reaching a decision. Vide Van Den Berghs Ltd. v. Clark  1 .

holdings.text: a contract entered into in the ordinary course of business... any receipt on account of such a contract can only be a trading receipt

anchor.surface_text: But this cannot be said of a contract entered into in the ordinary course of business. Such a contract is part of the business itself, not anything outside it as is the agency, and any receipt on account of such a contract can only be a trading receipt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trading contract is the business itself (supplying limestone), unlike agency which is apparatus leading to business; compensation adjusts trading rights/profits
